page.title: 15 History of Wolverhampton
page.content: Heantun was a Saxon village in a wood. A carved cross commemorates the victory of the Saxons against the Danes in 910. 985:King Ethelred gave land at Heantun to Lady Wulfrun who then gave it to the church. The deans of Wulfrun Heantun or Wolverhampton controlled the town.1180: Henry 111 granted a market charter.The market drew sheep farmers from Wales & the Midlands promoting prosperous wool trade. The Leveson family dominated the town's affairs.In 1590 fire burned many homes.Town surrendered to Parliament in Civil War. At Moseley Charles II hid at the Old Hall after defeat at Worcester. The 18th cent. was a time of religious intolerance but also economic progress. Canals and turnpikes were built. Trades included japanning, cut steel and lock making.From metal based crafts the town developed in modern times as a centre of engineering and technology.
